18976278.review:
Mushihimesama is a vertical Bullet Hell in where you play as a girl riding a giant beetle and shooting other giant bugs into oblivion. The reason why is explained at the end of the game but even then you will be left confused as to what happened and be left feeling like you just walked in to the ending of a movie with no context as to what it was about. Very few people go into a bullet hell expecting a engrossing story though I found it funny to be greeted with what was supposed to be a tear-jerking ending when the game didn't even so much as tell me the main character's name before that scene. It may sound weird to start off a review talking about the ending but this is a very short game and you will “beat it” in about half an hour or less, regardless of your skill level. This game features unlimited continues so everyone will be able to get through it if they are persistent enough. However the feature allowing you to save a replay of your play-through will cut off at the point you first lost all lives and had to use a continue. 

There are three modes to play here, them being Novice, Normal and Arrange. Novice is exactly what it sounds like and makes the game considerably easier by having less projectiles and simpler bullet curtains compared to Normal mode. This is definitely the mode to start with if you are new or out of practice to the genre. Arrange is a remix of the game that tweaks with certain aspects of the game that I will cover more thoroughly in a bit. Each mode minus Arrange has both score attack in which you compete with your friends and “play”. While in either mode you will have the option of either picking “Original”, “Maniac” for higher scores as well as more challenge and finally “Ultra”, for when you want to throw your controller/keyboard across the room in utter frustration at the real last boss wiping the floor with you. You will also be able to change the amount of lives you have and at what score you get more. Finally you will be able to pick which one of the three bullet formations you want to have, S-Power for a stream of condensed bullets for heavy damage, W-Power for a screen filling low damage attack and M-Power that is a mix of both. There are quite a bit of options for you to mess around with to say the least. 

Now that you are finally in the game and shooting bugs you will notice that this is pretty much what you would expect from a bullet hell. Bombs to clear the screen of projectiles, a counter to keep track of your score and a ton of enemies wanting nothing more than to shoot you out of the air. It does all of this very well and keeps you in a trance like state as you splatter all the bugs and collect all the yellow gems they drop to rake in a high score. Black enemy beetles carry power-ups so you will want to shoot these buggers down. The power-ups are either a small ally beetle that will shoot beams whenever you press the fire button, an upgrade to your projectiles or if you are about to fight a boss, a couple of bombs. A neat thing about the upgrade projectile power-up is that you can let its timer count down and it will change into a different type of shot. So say that you are shooting condensed projectiles but this part of the level is filled with a ton of enemies, simply wait for the power-up to change into a wide-shot formation and you will now have a much more suitable, screen filling projectile attack. This is a really neat system that makes it beneficial to learning the three projectile types instead of always sticking with what you know. 

Enemies in this game are huge and their size does matter as they will fire larger projectiles the bigger they are. That's not to say you shouldn't be cautious of the smaller enemies as well, since they fire tiny projectiles it can be easy for them to shoot you when you are focusing on a gigantic enemy. Remember that you are flying, you will be able to pass over some ground enemies when the amount of projectiles get intense and it seems there is nowhere to go. Projectiles are bright purple and very easy to spot, so if you get hit it will always feel like your fault. All of the five stages have a mid-boss that you will have to face and will leave if you take too much time with them. Bosses are where you will be most tempted to use your bombs as they will shower you with intricate bullet patterns. These moments are when you will most likely experience slowdown that will bring the action down to a crawl. The developers have stated that these are on purpose to give you a chance to react to all that is happening on screen though it would be nice to have an option to toggle the slow down on or off nonetheless. 

That finally brings us to Arrange mode. This is only a mode you'd want to play if you are already familiar with the game, it only has the ultra difficulty meaning the game is at its most brutal and you will have to face the aforementioned real last boss. She is the most shump/bullet hell boss I have ever encountered by far. It is an extremely difficult fight and to top it off she has an absurd amount of health. It will takes longer to whittle down her health and defeat her than it does to play through most of the game. Now with that out of the way onto what makes Arrange mode different from the other two modes. For one you start the game fully powered up and are able to kill the earlier enemies much easier than usual.  You will also have a feature most other games call “auto-bomb” which causes your character to automatically toss a bomb, clearing the screen when you are about to get hit. In this case she will throw all your bombs if you get hit, making your rate of survival much lower so you will not want to rely on that feature over your instinct of when to use them. The final thing that makes this mode much different is the ability to change your form of projectiles on the whim, to any of the three types available. 

Music in this game is a calm and soothing strangely enough. Stranger still is that it somehow fits in with the whole shooting giant bugs theme of the game. That is mostly due to the nice environments that range from flying over the water, across deserts and through giant trees. You will also be able to mix and match the music to play stages with either of the two soundtracks available. If you are playing this game horizontally you will be able to pick from 12 backgrounds to cover the parts of the screen that goes unused. Vertically is how this game was meant to be played, so if you have a monitor that can pivot that would be the ideal way to play this, though you can't go wrong either way. Annoyingly enough you will have to tweak the screen settings and the background in each of the three modes separately. One global setting would have been much preferred instead of having to tweak the game to our liking in all three modes. At the end of the day however, that is a minor complaint that will hopefully be fixed in a patch. This is a blast to play and due to its length won't take up much of your time in your attempts to master the game. Mushihimesama is an excellent bullet hell with plenty of content to keep you coming back and is hopefully the first in many of developer Cave's games to be released on the PC.

Mushihimesama is a japanese shoot'em up where you have to kill insects ( mushi means insect ) and dodge tons of missiles.
If you read recommandations, it might means that you are hesitant to buy these kind of games because they are usually really hard if you want to play correctly. Honestly, as a casual  shoot'em up player, i really enjoy this game. The different difficulties permits you to enjoy the game and progress step by step. 

Pros: Good graphics for a shmup
- Graduable difficulties
- You can play with a controller ( i use the Xbox 360 controller and it works well)
- Customizable game : if you prefer vertical or horizontal gameplay
- Infinite continues , for discovering the game and permits you to play at your level
 
Cons : The price

So if you want to discover these kinds of game, but are afraid about this "elite" genre, i'd recommand you Mushihimesama. If you are an advanced gamer, Mushihimesama is still good in many ways, there is many challenges ( no continues , have fun for the true last boss ! ;) )

 [*]贈送殺必思OST，而OST是很有誠意的FLAC無損檔。
[/list]
[list]
[h1]缺點[/h1]

[/list]

這遊戲看似虐手，但有擦邊慢速其實並不困難，normal一道破台還蠻容易的。

想起往日口袋有零錢就手癢的日子，到電玩店換個10枚20枚，放在機台上為了破台一道一道的投，就是壕啊。看到現在電玩店中，籃球機還比電動機台還多，壕氣不減但那台味已不在…真心祝福，彈幕的遊戲其實很浪漫。

18969449.review:
※STG初心者のレビューです
学生時代によく暇つぶしをしていた地元のゲームセンターで１クレジットプレイしたことがありますが、そのときは３分と持たず沈みました。
それから苦手意識を持ち、このジャンルのゲームはまったくといっていいほどプレイしたことが無かったのですが、今回懐かしさとリベンジで購入しました。

このSteam版では、当然ですがコンティニューにお金がかかりません。
というわけで１時間少々（８回か９回のコンティニュー）でノービスモードのオリジナルをクリアしました。
ゲーセンだったら1000円ですね。

クリアしたとき、過去の敗北感からか、やってやった感がすごかったです。
弾幕を潜り抜け（られてないしノービスだから大したことないのでしょうけど）、ボスを撃破したときの爽快感はなかなかのものだと思います。
グラフィックも綺麗ですし、音楽も雰囲気があっていいとおもいます。
正直、これ以外にもSTGやってみたくなってきました（もちろんアーケードはNG）。

相手がCPUで、素直な気持ちでトライアル＆エラーを楽しめますので、昨今の対人ゲームに疲れている方（私です）には非常にオススメです。

ゲーム性においてはほとんど悪い点がないのですが、ひとつだけ難点があります。
ウィンドウモードではゲーム画面が非常に小さいんです。
２７インチと１９インチで二画面構成にしているのですが、全画面にするとサブディスプレイが使えません。
最近のゲームはフチなし全画面ができるので問題ないのですが、このゲームにはその設定はおろかウィンドウのサイズ変更が２つしか用意されていません。
今は一応ウィンドウ内でゲーム画面の左右回転ができたのでそちらで対応しています。
が、見にくさはなかなかのもので、目が疲れるので継続プレイは難しいです。
この問題さえクリアしてくれればもっとがっつり楽しめるのかな、と思います。
これからの改善に期待しています。

それ以外はとても面白いので、目の疲れが取れたらまたプレイしたくなるくらい魅力があります。

長文になりましたが、購入をお考えの方の参考になれば幸いです。

18968740.review:
Finally, a Cave shooter on Steam. It is like a dream come true. The port is very good, with only a few hiccups being reported (none of which i have personally experienced) but the developoers appear to be very active and in fact they have already released a patch to fix several of them. The only caveat is a lack of resolution options. The game is set at 1280x720, same resolution as the Xbox version. I'm positive this will be addressed, but in the meantime you can use the GeDoSaTo utility developed by Durante (the same guy who gave us the wonderful Dark Soul fix). At high definition, the game looks very neat and sharp, like God intended! 

As for the game itself, this is one of Cave's best shooters and it oozes quality from every corner, from the vast array of gaming modes each offering unique bullet patterns to memorize and navigate through, to the complex scoring mechanic, all the way to the great visuals and music. Already clocked 8+ hours and will probably spend countless more trying to master all the various modes. There's even a novice modality for those new to the genre. Highly recommended.

普段はFPS，TPSを主に遊んでいる私ですが、虫姫さまは縦STG文化圏の端っこにいる私のようなユーザーへの門戸も広く作られており、ノービス、コンティニュー数回でエンディングまでたどり着けるので、初心者でも十分に楽しめます。

18961242.review: Debutto esplosivo nel mondo PC per gli shmup bullet-hell made in Cave, dove Degica ne ha curato il port, praticamente identico alla versione HD uscita per Xbox360 nel 2012. Meno iconica rispetto a serie come Deathsmiles e DoDonPachi, il primo Mushihimesama resta una perla irrinunciabile per gli appassionati che troveranno un tasso di sfida importante (ma sempre modulabile), crudo e senza orpelli. Una curva meno accessibile rispetto ad Espgaluda II o DoDonPachi Resurrection (in pratica se colpiti si muore, niente bomba salvavita, eccetto quando si gioca in arrange). A garanzia di maggior pregio si può considerare come novità qui in occidente, contando solo una uscita su iOS nel 2011, è pur sempre rimasto region lock su console e arcade giapponesi. Peccato che il mode 1.5 sia a pagamento e non incluso. Resta comunque altamente consigliato, infine suggerisco caldamente di usare il joypad.

======

7.游戏本身没啥说的，也不是第一次发售了，玩过的都知道。

9.即使有着这样那样的问题，仍然要买买买。价格已经够良心了，买到怒蜂系列都出来。

18952695.review:
CAVE's first appearance on Steam was received positively and made many people child-happy, myself included. 

The port is very good, although it has some [spoiler]bugs[/spoiler], which aren't game-breaking as far as I know.
It has 4 game modes to choose from, one of them being a DLC and each of them offers a different experience, which makes the game accessible to everyone (from complete beginners to superplayers).

Gameplay is solid and scoring can get fun, if you get deep into its mechanics. What I like about this game is that the movement is fluid, responsive and the tiny hitbox makes it possible to dodge various masses of bullets with ease if you know what are you doing. Music is good and the graphics are beautiful due to their crispness. Also, it offers customization for ex. screen display, background image, input display, detailed score ...

The only downside I can think of is the music for Arrange mode because it has little resemblance to the original one and i don't like its style. 

Otherwise, it's a great game and CAVE and Degica did a good job at bringing it to Steam. I hope we see more of it.

Whenever I get sick of shmups, cave shmups always bring me back in. Amazing game, beautiful art style, can be hard as balls but is still very fun. 

There are a few issues at launch, but they are relatively minor and have workarounds. They are currently working on a patch for these issues so expect many of them to be fixed soon. I still would recommend the game, even with the patch not out yet, since it is so much fun.

Edit: It's been a week or so, and still no local leaderboards. I'm switching my review to a no until they finally implement them.

Edit 2: They have finally added local scores being saved. Albeit it only saves the highest score. I would have preferred a full fledged leaderboard but, I'll cut my losses. This still works for me, and I can even see where my highest scores were at each part of the level. 

Switching my recommendation back to a yes for this one, and excited to dive back into the game.

18946843.review:
I have had to use a few work arounds to get the game running well, but overall I am happy with my purchase.  The core game is solid.  There are still a few bugs that need ironing out.  I am hoping that Degica will shift their focus after all their recent releases.  They need to work on polishing and fixing their games.  They did a fantastic job with Crimzon Clover, so I have faith that they will do the same here.  (Yotsubane deserves much of the credit for the Crimzon Clover support, as well.)

Here is some information that I haven't seen widely reported.  I recorded footage from the game with a 120 fps camera, and found that my inputs were responding around the the 13th frame.  This is 6 frames of lag at 60fps.  To put this in perspective, I tested Crimzon Clover with vsync and it had 5 frames.  I hope they can bring the lag down to that level.

My final thoughts are that this is Cave's first Steam release, so hopefully they can get better at dealing with PC related issues going forward.  I really urge people to purchase this game, so that we may get many more ports and maybe a new release.

18941944.review:

18941873.review:
This is a really good port of one of CAVES best shooters.  It's one of the more approachable bullet hell games they've made so it makes sense this would be the first one they bring over to get people interested over the arguably more difficult Dodonpachi Series.  Unlike other bullethell shooters, CAVE games don't rely on rote memorization to do well; They have a nice blend of freeform movement and tight bullet dodging which doesn't feel gimmicky or cheap.  If you're experienced in the genre or have good reflexes then even you can make it far on your first playthrough.

*The controls are as tight as they always were and every death will be your fault (no blaming th controls here :P)

*The game comes with 3 game modes (4 if you get the 1.5 DLC) each with 3 difficulty levels to control exactly how hard you want your experience to be.  You have Novice, Original, Arranged, and 1.5 (aka Matsuri).  Each has their own soundtrack which you can mix and match with other modes in the game in the options.  It's really customizable.  

*The visuals are really crisp and good looking.  It's only in 720p, but it doesn't take away from the art direction and the cleaness of everything presented.  The menu is very slick and easy to navigate.  You won't be entering and exiting a lot of menues to switch modes or play with options for each game.

*The framerate is great at least for me.  It switches between 59-60 fps during gameplay but I've never visually noticed or felt it. The main menu where you select which mode you want to play is 30fps but once you choose a mode it changes to 60.  There is slowdown during the game but IT'S 100% INTENTIONAL.  Cave's games have what's known as "earned" slowdown.  The game will LOOK like it's slowing down but if you look at your FPS counter it should still be +/-1 fps from 60 at all times during gameplay.  This is written 2 days after launch of the game but there have been framerate complaints from some people saying the game goes as low as 54fps for them.  I have a pretty basic non-gaming laptop and it runs fine for me.  I suspect it's some graphics card issue or they're running other programs in the background which might cause it to slow down.

All in all, if you are a veteran or a newbie trying to get into the genre then you can't go wrong with this quality title.

18939590.review: This game is really, really good. The various modes make sure that everyone can have fun playing, from newcomers to the genre to people much, much better than I could ever hope to be! Layer upon layer of strategy, challenge, beauty, and pure honest fun. In a world of esports, VR, and open world epics, Mushihimesama has a refreshing purity that reminds me why I came to love videogames in the first place. Fire. Dodge. Die. Figure out why. Repeat. And keep shooting for that high score or one-credit clear. It's tempting to say they don't make 'em like this anymore, but Mushihimesama's release on Steam is hopefully a sign of much more to come, both new and old, from our fiendish friends at CAVE. A must play - you won't regret it!

18939572.review:
[Final update]

Game now runs near-perfectly. I am not a hardcore expert at it, so I can't say if every little detail is correct now, but everything I see now works as intended. And this is one of the best games of its type on Steam, so I am changing my rating appropriately. 

Kudos to the devs for working hard to fix everything.

Original review:

Full of bugs, but not the ones you were hoping for. 

No proper resolution options, no global scaling options for all game modes, sound quality issues, graphical issues, crashes, black screens, framerate problems, runs at different speeds in windowed and fullscreen modes, problems with saving high scores, leaderboard problems, you name it. 

There's an absolutely wonderful game underneath it all, but I can't give this a pass just because it's a Cave game. Buy now if you're a die-hard fan, otherwise wait until they squash all those nasty bugs and deliver us some cool ones.

游戏是绝对的好游戏。CAVE的经典代表作之一，CAVE的STG质量是毋庸置疑的优秀。可能是因为首次登陆steam的试水作，多多少少还是出现了一些小问题（帧数有些不稳定，有些特殊键位比如shift不允许使用，分辨率问题），不过并不能掩盖游戏本身的优秀。爽快的射击体验，优秀的操作手感，音乐的完美配合，已经足够了。当然，小的瑕疵希望能尽快修复。

如果你喜欢STG，那么绝对不要错过这款游戏。

期待CAVE的下一作移植。

18928115.review:
I'm not an afficionados of shoot'em up or Bullet Hell games, but I like the genre. I knew Mushihimesama before, so I was sure that the game would be pretty good. It's a port of an HD version that came out on xbox, so the game really is for everyone. You have several modes that will challenge you at your rythm, and a ton of options suit your preferences.
The art is great, in a world infested by insects, like Nausicaa, a girl will try to reason with the leader to ensure mankind survival.
The musics are very catchy, very "arcad-ish" and remixes are available in the Arrange 1.5 mode.
TLDR : great game if you wan't to get into the bullet hell genre, or if you want some challenge.

PS: At the moment(November 7th), people are experiencing a few bugs, (crashes, and leaderboard not working) but it will be fixed soon. Devs are working on it

벌레들의 공주님이 임기가 끝나는 2018년 2월 24일까지...아니 이게 아니라....심장에 야수들이 쏘는 탄알을 맞기 전까지 살아남으면서 모든 야수들을 때려잡고 끝내 숲의 신까지 때려잡은 후 최후의 일인자가 된다는 내용의 게임입니다.

종스크롤 탄막게임의 기념비적인 작품으로써 해당 장르의 팬일 경우에 소장가치는 충분하다고 여겨지므로 추천을 할 수 있는 게임입니다.

18925823.review:
Ich bin noch sehr neu in diesem Genre und habe nicht sonderlich viel Erfahrung mit Shmups. Wenn man ein bisschen auf Youtube nach dem Genre sucht stößt man eher früher als später auf Mushihimesama. Das Spiel gibt es beispielsweise für die Xbox schon seit längerem, aber da ich keine besitze habe ich mich umso mehr gefreut, dass dieses Spiel endlich auf Steam erhältlich ist. Und nach ein paar wenigen Spielstunden ist mir schon klar warum der Name ziemlich oft fällt, wenn man von Shmups liest.

Für unerfahrene Spieler wie mich ist der Novice Modus ein sehr netter Einstieg in dieses Genre. Die Steuerung hat man schnell intus und man wird angenehm gefordert. In anderen Shmups hatte ich das Problem kaum einen nennenswerten Fortschritt zu spüren, bin schier verzweifelt und habe sie dann schließlich erstmal beiseite gelegt. Im Novice Modus von Mushimimesama merke ich jedoch wie ich langsam besser werde. Nach vier Stunden schaffe ich es schon ohne ein Leben zu verlieren in die Mitte der dritten Stage und auch wenn dieser Fortschritt langsam klingen mag fühlt er sich für mich gut und richtig an. In Normal oder Arrange schaffe ich es ohne Continue noch nicht so weit, aber selbst da bin ich nicht völlig verloren. Selbst wenn ich dort in Stage 2 noch aufgeschmissen bin fühlt sich das Spiel aufregend an und macht sehr viel Spaß. Ich kann es mit meiner wenigen Erfahrung nicht wirklich beurteilen, doch spätestens im Modus V1.5(der leider nur kostenpflichtig als DLC erhältlich ist) auf Ultra werden sicher auch Profis schnell an ihre Grenzen kommen.

Unter'm Strich denke ich, dass Mushimimesama wahrscheinlich ein sehr guter Titel für Einsteiger ist, an dem man viel Spaß haben und wachsen kann. Die hübsche Grafik und der ganz nette Soundtrack tun ihr übriges.

Das einzige derzeit noch große Manko für mich ist, dass Highscores nicht local gespeichert werden. An dieser Stelle muss dringend nochmal nachgepatcht werden.

18925281.review: Great oldstyle shooting game from Japan, ported from XBOX360. Original was released for arcade game in 2005. The first version on Steam contains some bugs especially for the fullscreen issue, hopefully fixed soon. My recommendation is to purchase the "Matsuri-pack", the full version inclusing "version 1.5", which is slightly different with original version. This is Cave's entering title for Steam, and hoping the latter title "Mushihimesama-Futari" and its "black label" on it very short time.

もちろんCAVEらしくプレイヤーを容赦なく殺しに来るモードもあり、上級シューターでも満足できるタイトルでしょう。

ただ解像度が縦横比で固定されているなど、PC用として最適化されているとは言い難い部分もあり、良くも悪くも家庭用をそのまま持ってきた感じが否めません。
その辺りは今後のアップデートでの改善を期待します。

前述のとおりゲーム自体は非常に面白いので、多少細かいところに目を瞑れるのであればおすすめできるタイトルです。

18914378.review:
This port is Dark Souls quality. That this is based on the Xbox 360 version is apparent with all the same menus and such. What makes it even more apparent are the little amenities made for the PC and the introduced issues:

-The game is locked to horizontal 720p.
-This means vertical mode (TATE) must be used in a horizontal resolution.
-Movement is hard-bound to the arrow keys. (This will be addressed in an upcoming patch)
-Keybindings are thankfully available, however, half of my keyboard doesn't seem to be recognized.
-There are crashes upon pressing Start at the title screen, entering/exiting a game mode, and quitting the game. (Pressing Alt+Tab or waiting a few beats before doing the action might help you, but there are some gamers who can't get around these crashes at all. This will be addressed in an upcoming patch too.)
-I'm not sure if it's just me, but sometimes I find Reco continue moving in a direction a split second after I stopped pressing into that direction.
-Sometimes, the main menu items disappear upon returning from a game mode.

To fix some of these issues, particularly the crashes and locked resolution and even frame rate ones, look up GeDoSaTo and set it up.

Past these flaws, the game itself seems to run beautifully. The new HD visuals are more pleasing on the eyes compared to their blurry arcade originals. I can't comment on the accuracy of slowdown compared to the Xbox 360 version or the arcade PCB, but Degica did get members of the shmup community who own either versions to playtest.

If you're new to shmups, then this game might seem too overpriced for what seems like a quick half-hour affair, but that's ignoring the brilliance of arcade gameplay that truly shines when you aim to complete the game in only one credit (1CC, one credit clear) without any continues. Probably the best analogy for this post-arcade and post-NES age is speedrunning. As you play through the stages over and learn from your mistakes, you start learning the stages and developing all sorts of strategies and techniques to carry you over to the final goal of surviving the entire game. That alone will give you hours upon hours of gameplay. If you enjoy the game and want even more hours of gameplay, then you can kick up the difficulty and this game offers in addition to Original, Maniac and Ultra. Or you can start getting into scoring and aim for the global high scores. Or you can check out the other modes that come with this game.

The new modes give a great shakeup with Arrange being a full-powered big numbers scoring affair (with autobombs) and 1.5 injecting more excitement into the base game with a stronger shot, more pronounced slowdowns, and an emphasis on point-blanking along with some tweaking to the stages. Personally, 1.5 is a must-have and it really makes this port so grab that too.

While Mushihimesama isn't my favorite Cave game, I could see why this would be their first released title. This game (Xbox 360 version) never got a region-free release. It also has an emphasis on styilized slowdowns as if you're dodging in bullet time, which is a nice introduction for newcomers to the bullet hell genre. Another newbie-friendly mechanic is the consistent use of bullet-canceling. Throughout the stages, there are huge enemies that spit out massive bullet patterns and if they are defeated, then all the bullets on the screen disappear into gems, giving you a breather and encouraging you to gather as many bullets as possible. There is also a focus on the basic manuvering skill of going from one side of the screen to another as opposed to the more complex approaches of other Cave games. 

The scoring mechanics are also fairly simple too. Original focuses on doing chip damage, destruction of boss parts, and surviving. Maniac/Ultra are about boosting up the multiplier by controlling your shot rate against certain enemies from certain positions on the screen to milk them for points before destroying them, and then chaining from one enemy to another to maintain the multiplier and prevent it from decreasing. Arrange/1.5 modes introduce point-blanking for gems. On top of all this are other minor mechanics such as the aforementioned bullet-canceling or "no-missing" (never dying within a stage for bonus points). Personally, the base game scoring mechanics aren't my cup of tea because the multiplier mechanic is very particular, but I do like point-blanking.

Cave is making a huge entry on Steam with this game, and if you buy this game, then you're telling them that there is a future for their shmups, because they are planning to make new ones on Steam beyond ports of their prior titles. 

I'm going to end this review with a tip. Did you know? Reco doesn't wear panties.

看上去酸爽依旧的弹幕~ 其实自机中弹判定并不大，休闲模式下弹幕速度不快躲开并不难，感觉比怒首领蜂的弹幕稍难一点，找回了当初在PS2上战虫姬那种越被虐越兴奋的感觉。只是不能1080P、帧数有点不稳定（GTX760显卡帧数在55-60之间徘徊）有点遗憾，但瑕不掩瑜，游戏本身素质颇高，除开情怀已值回票价。

操作一流，连打射击和按压减速射击相辅相成切换自然。画面优美背景绚丽，敌方虫类怪物的设定很有特色（当然讨厌昆虫的话我们另说....），同时对很多STG游戏分不清背景、奖分和子弹的朋友说一句：虫姬敌方子弹统一为紫色很好分辨，万花丛中一点紫非常清晰，这点必须给赞。音乐优美（战斗中都忙着躲子弹去了无暇细听啊....OST下下来听吧~）

游戏总体好评，是近期值得入手的佳作（更何况已经国区定价+25%OFF了~）。作为一名STG游戏轻度患者（抖M...），对当年彩京CAVE双雄争霸百花齐放的STG鼎盛时代真是无比怀恋，话说彩京啥时候能把1945系列和战国系列（至今记得战国之刃选隐藏机体的方法）在steam上出一遍？到时也一定毫不犹豫的剁剁剁啊！

18911730.review: Cave has finally come to Steam! An excellent game to start with, Mushihimesama is one of Cave's finest.

18911341.review:
================
Quick Review 
================

Control [5/5]
With some of the sharpest control around, even with an analog stick, Mushihimesma's control is simply amazing.  Any controller at all will have you playing like a pro in no time. 

Challenge [5/5]
Some of the most difficult Bullet Hell gameplay is yours to challenge in Mushihimesama...If you want to. Novice modes allow for newbies to get in on the fun too. 

Length [5/5]
There are so many modes available to play even without the DLC Version 1.5 that bullet hell fans are sure to get solid weeks of gameplay out of Mushihimesama. Players will definitely spend a decent amount of time finding the best mode for them. Our picks go to Novice and Arrange. 

Visuals[4.75/5] 
Mushihimesama has some really cool looking visuals, but they are definitely not as polished at Muhihimesama Futari would later be.  Regardless amazing anmiation and awesome design oozes - sometimes almost literally - from this game. 

Sound [4/5]
One of the better OSTs to come from Cave, Mushihimesama narrowly beats Futari in terms of composition...so it's kind of a shame that the bitrate for many of the tunes here, especially in Version 1.5 make for a very washed out sounding audio presentation. Ouch. 

Ingenuity [4.25/5]
There's no denying that Mushihimesama paved the way for great things in the future. While not as polished as its obviously superior successor, Mushihimesama has features that still make it worth playing regardless.

WATCH THE FULL REVIEW
https://youtu.be/0dbqSmSg71U

18911133.review: CAVE's bullet-hell/danmaku shmup debut on Steam. Buy it even if you understood only half of these words!

18910679.review:
Cave's Steam debut title is a sought after game now available outside of Japan. Mushihimesama screams classic bullet-hell action that'll put your skills to the test. 5 stages with intense bosses along with an arrange version as well as the once limited 1.5 version now optional DLC. This is a title that is extremely welcomed addition into Steams growing library in the genre.


[b] Pros: [/b]
[*]Each of the main modes offer something different for a variety of skill levels
[*]The 3 power ups offer a slightly different playstyle
[*]A good variety of enemies. The huge 3D characters looks especially nice in action
[*]The once limited 1.5 version is available ( although its offered as DLC)
[*]Along with the catchy tones, theres also a couple of remixed tracks that you can change and mix up for each of the main modes
[*] The game's novice mode is a welcoming addition for those who may be new to the genre
[*]Thousands of bullets to dodge!

[b] Cons: [/b]
[*]Limited resolution at standard HD (720p). Only offers window and full screen.
[*]Small minor stutters during gameplay
[*]FPS seems to be set around 55-57
[*]1.5 Version has some audio quality issues
[*] Cloud feature isnt fully functional, but could be fixed with a patch

[b] Verdict: [/b] THUMBS UP! I highly reccomend this game for fans of bullet-hell titles that are hungry for a challenge. Aside from a few minor issues ( which has been said that at least some of the immediate issues will be patched), this is a much welcomed title in Steam's library that could open doors for Cave to release more of their bullet-hell classics in the future.

18910483.review:
ケイブSTGの中では最もシンプルな部類で、癖がない”普通の弾幕STG”。
見た目がちょっと蟲ですが、変わったシステムもなくてとにかく普通。
ケイブらしくなく、ストーリーも普通にちょっと切ない感じで、
ホモもいないし、性転換もしないし、張り手も飛んでこないので安心です。

普通ですけど完成度も普通に高く、音楽もド安定の並木と、
Steamの数少ないSTGの中でやはり頭一つ抜きん出た存在かと。

弾幕STG敬遠してる人にも入門作として勧めやすいので、一作目がこれなのは正解かも。
難しいイメージがあるかもしれませんが、楽しむ程度なら敷居はそんな高くないです。
自機（と敵弾）の当たり判定が見た目より小さいということさえ理解できれば、後は慣れ。
というか綿密なパターン必須の昔のSTGの方が個人的には難しい…
アドリブでなんとかなるので、なんとなくで遊べます。

ちなみに弾幕系じゃないモードもあるので、それ目当てで買って、
気が向いたら弾幕モード挑戦してみる感じでもいいんじゃないでしょうか。

欠点としてはまぁ普通過ぎることです。
STGよくやる人にとってはちょっと物足りない。飽きやすい。
ケツイと最大往生はよ。
けど次は虫ふたかデスマかなーガルーダかもなー。

但是，可能是第一次，这次出现了很多问题：

18908986.review: Let me tell you this is one addictive game.  Novice mode is super fun (press left on the main screen to access it) if you are not that good at shmups, and with 3 levels of difficulty for every mode, this game has tons of replay value.  You may want to read a scoring guide online (google will find one for you fast) to get the most out of this game, as there is no tutorial or instructions to speak of.  Try playing this with headphones...the soundtrack will blow you away though you may want to buy the soundtrack to listen to separately as it can be hard to focus on the music with so much happening on the screen!  My 2 gripes about this game are that the resolution options are not that great and that there is no explanation of the scoring, power-up items, or story in-game.  I would have at least liked some info to cover what a typical arcade pop might have, which would include what different icons mean and explanation of the shot types.  For the resolution issue, at least you can get the playfield the size you want it by adjusting the zoom, position, and zoom of the x and y axis separately, though it's hard to tell if you are playing on an arcade-accurate size ratio at that point.  Also, this must be done after choosing your mode, so you will need to set this 4 times (3 if you don't buy the DLC...but buy it).  Despite these problems I do not regret buying this game as it really shows why Cave is the master of this genre, I mean I was pretty much addicted after the first minute of playing and cannot wait to really get more into it!

18906751.review:
If you're a Mushihime veteran just looking to know if this is a good port or not, the answer is yes.  It doesn't have a lot of uber PC master race settings like resolutions above 720p, but the gameplay is intact and then some, and it beats the heck out of paying out the butt for the PS2 or 360 versions.

If you're otherwise wondering if this game is for you... that depends.

If you want old-school, masochistic, NES era Gradius style challenge, you won't find it here... unless you try for the True Final Boss (hereafter referred to as "TFB").  To get to him, you must beat the game on Maniac or Ultra without continuing.  ...Or just play through Arrange mode, which is a special mode with it's own rules, which happen to include giving you access to the TFB.  Everything else in the game however is easily accessible as the game gives you unlimited continues, and as of this review, there's no way to turn them off.  You can not use them, but eh...

But if that's what you're looking for, get something like Gundemonium Recollection or Jigoku Kisetsukan: Sense of the Seasons instead (the latter of which is free).

What you will find here however is still quite an amazingly well designed shooter with gorgeous art, a lovely soundtrack, and tons of replay value, especially if you're competitive (there's online leaderboards in this version), love to focus on personal improvement, want to get all the Steam achievements, and/or actually ARE going for the TFB.

And to be fair, the unlimited continues aspect also gives the game a certain flexibility... you can get good at the game at your own pace, or just play it to veg out at your computer without worrying about death, or get a better idea of how all the levels and modes differ without looking at a guide, etc.

I just want to be transparent and helpful about this feature, as it's a bit of a controversial one in shmups that can make or break a game for many people.  Myself included in some cases.  Yes, this game has unlimited continues on all modes and difficulties, and there's no way to disable it.  Whether that's a good or bad thing, I leave up to you.  Both approaches have different things to offer with their own advantages and disadvantages.

On the merits of the game's overall design however, I do absolutely recommend it.  Just know what you're getting into.  It's a game you'll finish in 45 minutes if you just play through it... or a game that'll take countless hours of your time if you wanna go deeper.

18904853.review:
Let's be honest here. All of my friends know me as a bullet hell fanatic. When my friends told me that Jamestown was awesome, I played through that so much, I almost got burnt out. In fact, I did.

I haven't played "You know what" in years and I felt kinda rusty...

And then I decided to reinstall Steam because certain other games caught my eye and what did I find when I came home from work today...

....CAAAAAAAAVE.

I don't own any iteration of XBox, nor an iPhone/Pad. I've never known the joys of DoDonpachi or Espgaluda. I've wanted to play a CAVE game SOOOOOO bad for years now, and I've finally gotten the chance.

Going into the game, I could honestly find little faults. To be fair, its because this laptop is fairly old, so I'm used to playing on lower resolutions to save framerate. Not that it means anything. I know CAVE has intentional framerate slows at points so the game isn't TOO hard when you're staring at an almost filled ellipse of purple death. In either case, if you're familiar with cave, you know the bullet patterns are always fair, no matter how harsh they may seem. Always remember that the bullet size isn't indicative of its own hitbox, and if you learn their hitboxes, you'll get the hang of dodging relatively quickly. Novice is well, novice. There's more breaks in patterns, some stage enemies don't fire at all anymore, etc. Its great for beginners. Standard is exactly what it says. Play Maniac on standard or above for a fun time. (If you're new you might even experience the rare occurance of smashing a keyboard/controller in frustration! But that's part of the learning process.)

In short, if you've heard of CAVE, buy this game. If you like bullet hell games, buy this game.

No seriously, buy it. Probably the best $14.99 (soon to be $19.99) you'll have spent in a good long while. Plus it hopefully will convince CAVE to release Ketsui and DoDonpachi on Steam as well!

18903902.review:
This has been a long time coming. Cave on STEAM. Time to dive right on in the Mushihimesama First mode I tried was arranged mode and I jumped right in for some good'ol fashioned score attack. What looks like a punishing barrage of bullets comes out to be very manageable as long as you breathe, don't panic, and pay attention. Nothing in this game is impossible outside of the most ludicrous difficulty. Don't take what I'm saying as the game being easy. It isn't. You'll be praying for some slowdowns to hit left and right in no time. It does help ease those in who are new to the genre and continues to step up the difficulty all the way until the end. The game does give beginners ample tools to help enjoy the game all the way until the end. It's up to the player to get their selves off the training wheels. 

The game offers various difficulties, modes, ships (beetles) for you to heep on to your plate. Each mode offers different speeds, enemy patterns, bullet patterns, and all that other deliciousness to keep you busy for hours on end. Score Attack allows you to take on each mode with locked in game options to compete for highscores against fellow players. I'm already finding this to be my go to mode. For those looking for a more soothing experience you can go to novice mode and crank everything down all the way so you can enjoy artwork and exploding beetles while relaxing to some wonderful tunes that this game has to offer. 

The presentation, art direction, and music for this game is fantastic. The game has beautiful menus with an array of backgrounds with music that will make you glad that you got this game early for that free soundtrack. The backgrounds and enemies make me want to crank the difficulty all the way down so I can take the time to admire the work CAVE put into designing and animating these bugs. On the other spectrum I want to crank the difficulty up so I can appreciate the beautiful bullet spreads that this game throws at you. If only I were good enough to make it to the end to enjoy them all.

Can't wait to get back into this game and sink some hours of my life into it. While I'm in no way close to being decent at shmups, this game makes me feel like I'm somewhat competent. The game does a great job of building player confidence and even when I died I rarely felt like it was because the game was unfair. It helps make me want to get better at memorizing enemy and bullet patterns so I can shoot for a 1CC.

18903899.review: Finally the first CAVE game to arrive on Steam! Beautiful graphics and OST, this manic shooter is a joy to play. If you've never played a bullet hell shmup before, prepare to overclock your brain!!

18903835.review:
Mushihimesama or known also as (Bug Princess) is a Arcade game originally released in 2004 from Cave Interactive only available in Japan. But thanks to the company Degica Games they have finally decided to bring this true gem of a Bullet Hell to the PC Steam Market. 

The Story of the game is about A world of wild insects roaming the lands who are capable of surviving due to rock hard shells. When eventually dying they leave behind vegetation that grows around them in a Great Circle of Life style (Living and then dying as a nature tale.) Due to them being poisonous though humans were not all able to survive infact needing to sacrifice every 200 years a 15 year old girl. Reco the next girl in line and one of the Royal family members of the last remaining village is the next to perish on the day of her 15th birthday who decides to save her people by embarking on a quest to meet the God of the Insects known as the Koujuu.

Gameplay: This game is a complete arcade port of the original game offering a variety of different gameplay features ranging from Novice, Normal, Arrange, and Version 1.5 (One of the hardest modes  to tackle)

The Game features Controller and Keyboard support but also lack no 1080p display sadly as of (up till writing this review)

Other than a few small glitches at first start up this game is a complete powerhouse packed with content and tons of replayability and if you are a fan of Bullet Hell, Space Shooting, or Shmup games I think you will find your enjoyment in Mushihimesama.

Included is my First Impression of the game I hope you enjoyed and felt my review to be the worthy one in involving your purchase for Mushhimesama.

https://youtu.be/JEC0SW7wXhc

18903799.review:
Simply put, one of the best Arcade shooters ever made, finally available for the PC audience to enjoy.  Previously, you would have needed to import a Japanese Xbox 360 or convince yourself that the touchscreen controls for the smartphone version felt right to be able to play it...but now you can have the real deal and it is worth the wait.  The game features excellent music, gorgeous sprites and killer Bullet Hell twitch play the way only the masters of the genre, CAVE, can deliver.   It's a challenge but there are "Novice" modes included to help beginners get a feel for the game.  The other modes are, to be expected, merciless...the game will steal your lunch money, hand it back to you, pimp smack you and steal it again.  Make no mistake, this is for the hardcore.  That being said, it is remarkably fun and satisfying to play.  It's also somewhat of a small miracle to see it come to the PC.

The one issue I encountered was a couple crashes when I first changed the settings to allow Full Screen in the options menu.  Apart from that, the game runs silky smooth and it comes with my highest recommendation.  Get it now so CAVE can bring more of their titles to the PC!

18903789.review:
2004年にゲームセンターで稼動された同名縦スクロールシューティング（弾幕系）のPC移植版。

このSteam版は2012年に発売されたXBOX360版をベースとした移植でグラフィックスの高解像度化に加え、シューティング初心者向けの「ノービスモード」や先に移植されたPS2版とは異なる「アレンジモード」の2つの追加モード。

そしてオプション面ではこの手のゲームではおなじみのモニターを縦にして遊ぶ「縦画面モード」のほかに画面左右の余白にスコアや残ボム数の拡大表示や各ステージのスコア統計などを表示できる「エキストラウィンドウ機能」。

さらに「オリジナル」「アレンジ」の2種類あるBGM（DLCの「Ver1.5」を導入するとこれに加え「Ver1.5」も追加される。）を各ステージごとに設定できたり、連射ボタンの設定がやけに細かかったりする等、良くも悪くもXBOX360版のほぼベタ移植。
（もちろん、難易度や残機などの設定を変えてしまうと実績が解除できないところも同じ。）

ゲームのほうは色々な方面で初心者から超上級者まで幅広く楽しめると言われているとおり、やや「萌え」に偏ったキャラに抵抗が無ければ、新設された｢ノービスモード」のおかげでシューティング初心者でも十分に楽しめるし、それで物足りなければアレンジモードやDLCの「Ver1.5」で遊べばかなり歯ごたえのある内容になるなど、個人的に幅広い層のシューティング好きに対応している間口の広さが個人的に良い感じだった。
（ちなみにDLCのVer1.5はXBOX版ではパッケージ版の初回封入特典でしか手に入らなかったが、こちらは有料とはいえ、普通のDLCとして売られているのは個人的に好感が持てる。）

一応動作のほうもCore i3必須と書かれているが私の環境である「Pentium G3220 ＠3Ghz＋GeForce GTX650」環境ではプログラムによる意図的な処理落ちを除いて変な処理落ちなどが無く快適に遊ぶことが出来た。
（ちなみにプレイ中のCPU使用率は大量に弾が出てくるシーンでも大体30％ー40％でたまに70％出てくる程度。ただ、ステージクリア時は一瞬だけ90％近くに上がることがあった。もちろん動作保障外の環境なので動かす際は自己責任で、、）

ただ、現在（11月11日）のVerではたまに敵が出てくる際、少し動きが引っかかる感じになることがあるのが少し気になる。

あと、アーケード完全移植派にとってはXBOX360版初期のケイブシューのように高解像度Verの他にアーケード版と同じ解像度のVerも収録してほしかったところ、、

まぁ、色々と書いたが「斑鳩」や「クリムゾンクローバー」などと同様、Steamで売られているシューティングとしてはかなり良作の部類の入るので興味があればぜひ、、

18901835.review:
While my money was on [i]Dodonpachi[/i], I have to admit that Mushihimesama is the best choice for Cave's first game on Steam. Before you start asking what a "Dowhatawhat" is, allow me to explain. Cave is an STG* developer commonly known for their "bullet-hell" games. The foundation of STGs is the prevalence of tiny instant-death orbs, so a barrage of them is a truly fearful sight. 

In a way, Mushihimesama was conceived to be an "Anti-Cave" shooter. Like a number of STG companies in the mid-90s, Cave was born from the ashes of Toaplan. Before declaring bankruptcy in 1994, Toaplan was a giant in the STG world. Their games were often high-quality, and relied mostly on traditional mechanics and scoring systems. When playing a Toaplan shooter, you weren't concerned about "medal-chains", you were struggling to survive. As intimidating as the average danmaku spread is; faster, more focused shots can be just as threatening. In [i]Dodonpachi[/i] you'll easily cut through battalions of tanks, but in [i]Twin Cobra[/i], one tank is usually enough to spell your doom.

Reco is just your ordinary princess in an extraordinary world. Atop Kiniro, her trusty beetle, she must face innumerable dangers in order to rescue her homeland from a deadly force. You have an odyssey of your own to undertake, because Cave has put two generations of STGs into one tight package. While you may or may not be a veteran of the genre, you always have to consider the basics. In the age of danmaku, we see plenty of bullets, but all too often, we forget where they came from. For the most part, all we know is that we'll stay alive as long as we continue dodging them.

To really grasp what makes a 2D shooter work, we have to consider the origins of the bullet, hence "Original" mode. In this mode, the bullets are minimal, quick, and very direct. Your first instinct will always be to stay as far away as possible. This means hiding out at the bottom of the screen. A very important aspect of STGs that we tend to ignore, is that enemies are shooting to kill. They aren't spreading bullets all over the screen for their health, they're aiming for you. This is subtle, but if you pay attention in between the waves of projectiles, you'll see cannons turning in your direction, and the eyes of adversity following your movements. Staying far away merely to give yourself the most reaction time, probably isn't the best idea.

The maneuvers that you perform before the bullets are fired, are just as if not more important, than maneuvers made after bullets appear on-screen. Every enemy in this game has their own attack-pattern. When a stage begins, you might see one or two creatures perform this attack, but by the end of the stage, their numbers increase substantially. These foes will combine their efforts with others (also introduced earlier) to make your life miserable. By memorizing their patterns and locations, you've got an advantage, which is a very rare occurence in the STG world. With this knowledge, you can "lead" enemies into firing at where you were, instead of your current position. Eventually this will minimalize those frantic situations where you're trying to dodge everything at once. Don't get me wrong, that's always fun, but not really conducive to survival.

You also have to consider the psychological aspect. All it takes to die in this game is one bullet, and even Original mode throws out hundreds of thousands. When the situation becomes desparate, you can throw out a bullet-clearing bomb. Bombs in a Cave shooter tend to penalize the player's score, but they also carry more insidious aspects. In short, bombs are a weapon that is used against you. In a genre where life and death are measured in pixels, do you ever really [i]need[/i] to bomb? Even thinking about the "B" button on your joystick is drawing focus away from the action. Oft-times, you "panic-bomb", which mentally shakes you. Shortly afterwards you're liable to exhaust your stock, and your lives aren't far behind. This is all the more reason to learn enemies, their patterns, and how to lure their fire away.

That's just the fundamentals. There are still three more modes to test your abilities on. Maniac is about what you'd expect from a Cave shooter. The bullets fly a little slower, but they're far more plentiful, and much more ornate. Still, what you learned in Original will help you here. A lot of enemy-fire can still be led away, and even though every bullet is similarly-shaped and colored, you'll know exactly what is firing from where, so hopefully you can avoid terrible situations. Unlike Original mode, where the bulk of your points comes from remaining lives at the end of the game (if you get that far), Maniac has a complicated scoring system. It involves something called counter-banking and...uh...in the interest of sanity (and character limits), I recommend looking up a guide or watching replays. One of the handy features this game offers is the option to turn on an "input window". Basically this shows exactly what joystick movements and button-presses are being made. When you watch a replay off of the online leaderboards, you can get an idea of what the top players are doing to get their hi-scores.

Unfortunately there's only so much that can prepare you for Ultra mode. Just to give an example of just how difficult things get, I'll share my experience with this port. The last time I played Mushihime-sama was nearly a decade ago. When I started this port, I managed to reach the 4th stage on Original and Maniac, on my first attempt. Ultra? I couldn't even get past stage 1. It'll take a herculean amount of effort to figure this nasty mode out. So feel free to give Arrange mode a look. I really like this mode, because getting high scores require that you get close to everything. Point-blanking an enemy in a 2D shooter is a very dangerous idea, but it can also be extremely thrilling. It's especially rewarding, when you discover those hidden safe-spots. Once you get accustomed to point-blanking, the other modes are going to seem a bit easier. You'll find yourself taking risks you never would have before, making subsequent attempts all the more interesting. The only complaint I have about Arrange is that the True Last Boss makes an appearance. In Ultra Mode, he's substantially more difficult than anything else in the game, which is saying a lot. Arrange mode is a little easier than Maniac, but when the TLB shows up, everything goes out of whack.

Regardless, this game is best experienced by spending time with every mode. You might think that you have to be able to master Original before you can move onto Maniac, but what's the that old saying? Rome wasn't 1CCed in a day? Ehh.. What I meant to say is that all these different modes exist for a reason. They're there to teach you about 2D shooters, and experience you gain in one mode can be shared with others. Yes, there are more bullets, and Maniac/Ultra/Arrange have scoring methods to consider, but stage layouts and fundamentals remain the same. There's also Novice and Training modes to help with your practice sessions.

All in all, Mushihimesama gets my highest recommendation, because it explains so much about how STGs work, without using a single word. The more you play the game, and its various modes, the more details you notice. Your play-style slowly evolves to fit the nature of the genre, and you begin to do things your past self could never even imagine. The gorgeous aesthetics and great soundtrack are icing on the cake. Oh and you'll definitely want to get the v1.5 add-on as well.

*2D shooters, Shmups, etc.

[i]Disclaimer: For the purpose of this review, a key was provided by the publisher.[/i]

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]

18901206.review:
Since the start of the Shoot-em-up genre, CAVE has served as the undisputed king. Their games often feature amazing art direction, unique yet fair mechanics, and lots and lots and LOTS of bullets. CAVE games have always had the unique mix of qualities that appeal to both the hardcore twitch-heavy shooter fan, and the casual amateur player just getting his feet wet in the genre. 

 In short, I recommend this game to everyone. If you are a SHMUP fan, you don't need me, you probably bought this purely on instinct. If you aren't familiar with this type of game, or are just getting started, I recommend this as well, as it is relatively simple (by CAVE's standards), with a welcoming difficulty curve. Plus, it is just a beautiful game on many levels. 

For the longest time, CAVE's games have been trapped in arcades, or limited console releases in Japan, only. The West has traditionally only seen one of these games released once in a while. With the modern growth of digital distribution, this is thankfully changing, and I expect (and hope) Steam will see more beautifully ported CAVE games such as this one.

The king has returned. All hail CAVE.

Serious review: Originally released in arcades in 2004, Mushihemesama(literally "insect princess/bug princess") is a bullet hell vertical scrolling shooter game released by CAVE. The game was not ported outside of Japan until 2011, where an iOS port, complete with translations, was released on Apple's App Store. On November 5th, 2015, the game was then ported to Steam worldwide, the first time a game by CAVE was released on Steam.

The port is very well done, offering a whole bunch of features along with the game. The Novice mode is great for introducing new players to the bullet hell genre, while still being fairly challenging. Visual options, such as windows that display stage score, high score, and closeups of ingame informations are added in for convenience. Controls can be fully and freely remapped, and you can choose between two(tree with the Version 1.5 DLC) different soundtracks to listen to ingame.

Overall this is a great port of a great game, and I feel that anybody who likes bullet hell or shoot 'em up games will enjoy this game greatly.

18900119.review:
Cave showed up late to the party on Steam. We've already got an enormous assortment of shmups from Jamestown to the charming Gundemonium Collection, to the esoteric Senko no Ronde stylings of Suguri and Acceleration thereof. Eschatos brings the old school style mixed impeccably with modern design expertise (And subtlety, how rare in this genre.), Ikaruga brings Treasure's take, CrimzonClover takes us on a wild roller coaster ride on a V2 missile that explodes gloriously, Exceed 3rd puts us somewhere south of Touhou, north of Cave, and even Sine Mora shows you what terrible shmups are like.

So where does that leave Cave?

We all already know. Their flavor of shmup is balls to the wall, sensory overload. Loads of quick bullets in lovely patterns, undeniably lovely environments and bosses before and after they are charred with your bullets. This is twitch gaming at its purest.

The port is lovely, runs beautifully, with all manner of options, but I have to bow to a true enthusiast to give a definitive answer.

But the game itself? Classic Cave shooting action without some of the esoteric nonsense scoring of their later years.

No I don't know what Arrange Mode means either but you have at least two different flavors of campaign, along with several difficulty levels.

18899924.review: THIS IS HOW YOU DO IT

18899866.review:
Ah, Mushihimesama. Translated to "Bug Princess" in English, it's one of CAVE's better bullet hell games, and probably one of the better known ones in the West, along with DoDonPachi. It doesn't surprise me in the least this is their first game on Steam, they sure love showing it off.

It's a great example of a CAVE bullet hell game, full of clever, harrowing bullet patterns and the simple CAVE gameplay. Not only are there the standard three game modes found in the original arcade release, this port includes a Novice mode with simpler bullet patterns (great for, well, novices, or losers like me who aren't that good at danmaku), an Arrange mode with different gameplay and music, and the V1.5 DLC includes a further arrangement of the basic gameplay, giving it a pallet swap and a third soundtrack to rock out to as well. 

The HD graphics are gorgeous, doing an wonderful job setting the Japanese fairy tale atmosphere, and the music is similarly excellent. The voice of the main character, Reco, might be a little grating, but it's part of the experience, I think. Not that I much mind it, anyway.

All three soundtracks (one only available with the V1.5 DLC) can be mixed and matched around the different game modes, which is a nice touch. You can also set the backgrounds during play to cycle on a timer, or manually switch between twelve, which is also nice, though the screen settings don't seem to save between different versions of the game. Meaning, if I mess around with the screen size in Novice mode, it won't show up in V1.5, and I'll have to do it over again. Not sure what that's about.

Unfortunately, the port quality is a bit dodgy. It seems to me they brought over the 360 version pretty much straight to the PC, for better or worse. You're locked into 1024x768 or 1280x720 for your screen resolution, windowed or fullscreen, which isn't...the best for modern computers. Furthermore, the game didn't actually recognize my controller properly, basically making it impossible to navigate the menus, though it wasn't anything x360ce couldn't fix.

I've encountered a few crashes as the game closes, which is probably also why my fullscreen settings don't save between sessions. Hopefully Degica will put out a few patches to smooth out a few of the rough parts, especially if they can add proper screen resolutions to the game.

There was also a minor SNAFU when the game was released, and I accidentally bought it plus the V1.5 DLC at full price, instead of with the launch discount. Considering I also got the soundtrack somehow, I'll call it even.

In closing, despite a bit of a shoddy port, Mushihimesama is still very much worth your time if you're a fan of danmaku/bullet hell. CAVE just about invented the genre, and they definitely do it best. Mushihimesama's just one of their many classics, and hopefully if it does well on Steam, we'll soon see DoDonPachi and Espgaluda, too!

18899257.review:
wahrscheinlich die schönste Kugelhölle aller Zeiten!

Mushihimesama ist ein toller Bullet-Hell Shooter von Cave, dem Entwickler, der das Genre mit Donpachi 1995 quasi erfunden hat. So geht es auch hier darum, sich unzähligen Gegnern zu erwehren, die unsere kleine Insektenprinzessin mit noch mehr Kugeln eindecken.
Die Insektoiden Gegner sind dabei sehr fantasievoll gestaltet, die Umgebungen abwechslungsreich und schön bunt! Mit Mushihimesama erschien 2006 in den japanischen Arcade Hallen eine Legende. Es gilt als eine der schwersten Kugelhöllen aller Zeiten, selbst erfahrene Shoot'm Up-Spieler stossen hier, vor allem im Ultra-Mode, an ihre Grenzen. 
Allerdings bleibt das Spiel immer fair. In all der bunten Detailfülle, die für ein Spiel, das einst auf PS2 erschien wirklich einzigartig ist, heben sich die feindlichen Kugeln und das eigene Feuer trotzdem immer schön von dem Untergrund ab. Ich wage zu behaupten, dass das Spiel mit all den Insekten das am schönsten gestaltete Shoot'm Up überhaupt ist.
Mushihimesama ist sicher auch für Genre-Einsteiger geeignet - nicht nur, weil es auch einen Anfänger-Modus gibt, sondern vor allem auch, weil das Scoring System weit weniger komplex ist als beispielsweise in einem Dodonpachi - im Standart Modus geht es im Prinzip einfach nur darum, möglichst viele Gegner über den Jordan zu schicken, bevor einen selbst dieses Schicksal ereilt. Somit war es sicher eine gute Entscheidung von Cave und Degica, dieses Spiel als erstes aus dem Cave-Portfolio auf Steam zu veröffentlichen - hoffen wir, dass noch viele folgen.
Dieses Shmup-Juwel war bisher nur Region-Locked für die japanische PS2, sowie in HD für die Xbox360 erhältlich. Freuen wir uns, dass sich Degica anschickt, noch weitere Kultspiele dieses Nischen-Genres auf Steam zu veröffentlichen. Das wird aber nur geschehen, wenn Mushihimesama ein Erfolg wird. Also: Kaufen! Die Ideale Möglichkeite, dieses Spiel ohne japanische Konsole nachzuholen, bzw. mit dem Danmaku (Bullet-Hell) Genre bekanntschaft zu machen! Neben Crimzon Clover und Ikaruga einer der Besten Shmups auf Steam!

18898768.review:
Not being a seasoned pro at shmups, I thought I'd give this a spin to see how good I was.

https://youtu.be/fnnwgCjLNls

This game is refreshing whilst posing an almighty challenge if you are a high score chaser.
Beautiful in its design and delivery, if you are a top-down fan I'd give this a spin. I need to pump more time into it to give a full and honest review, but what I've seen so far is very impressive. If you like bullet-hell shooters, grab this puppy!

18898645.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SWNiBk8Nq98

I would also like to add that I like the art in the game as well. Also I hope an OST will pop up eventually.

As for the port: It has  issues, some people are reporting crashes, but theya re thankfully in the minority. The game lacks gamepad support for anything aside from the 360 pad also the  controls are not entirely rebinadble, so no wasd movement for the keyboard.

The graphical options are also limited essentially having no resolution options at all and instead opting for  4:3 and  16:9 ratios which don't work on all systems (and  can lead to eye strain).

Aside from that the games itself is  alright, just wish the port  was better.
